Data.event_text: 2 January  Rail passengers face their biggest price increase for five years, with average tickets rising in cost by 3.4%.

links.text: -Topham, Gwyn (5 December 2017). "Train fares: UK rail passengers face biggest rise for five years". The Guardian. Retrieved 20 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 24 January  Storm Eleanor causes widespread disruption across the UK, with flooding and gusts of wind reaching 100 mph (161 km/h).

links.text: -"Storm Eleanor: Travel disruption and homes without power". BBC News. BBC. 3 January 2018. Retrieved 3 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 3 January  The NHS in England cancels all non-urgent treatments from mid-January until the end of the month, as reports emerge of patients facing long waits for treatment and being stuck on trolleys in corridors and of ambulances left queuing outside A&E.

links.text: -Therrien, Alex; Triggle, Nick (3 January 2018). "Health secretary Jeremy Hunt sorry as A&Es struggle to cope". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 3 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 5 January  Jon Venables, one of the killers of toddler James Bulger in 1993, is charged with possessing indecent images of children.

links.text: -"James Bulger killer Jon Venables charged over indecent images". BBC News. BBC. 5 January 2018. Retrieved 5 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 8 January  Theresa May announces a Cabinet reshuffle.

links.text: -Stamp, Gavin (8 January 2018). "Reshuffle: Lewis is new Tory chairman". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 8 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: The manufacture of cosmetics and personal care products with plastic microbeads is banned in England, with a ban on their sale due to come into force by July 2018.

links.text: -"Plastic microbeads ban enters force in UK". The Guardian. 9 January 2018. Retrieved 9 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: Virgin Trains announces it has stopped selling copies of the Daily Mail on its West Coast trains following "considerable concern [about] the Mail's editorial position on issues such as immigration, LGBT rights and unemployment".

links.text: -"Virgin Trains halts Daily Mail sales". BBC News. 9 January 2018. Retrieved 9 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 11 January  Theresa May pledges to eradicate all "avoidable" plastic waste throughout the UK by 2042.

links.text: -"Environment strategy aims to stop needless plastic waste". BBC News. 11 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 12 January  US President Donald Trump scraps a planned visit to the UK, blaming his predecessor, Barack Obama, for a "bad deal" on the new embassy due to be opened in London, despite the fact it was agreed under the administration of George W. Bush.

links.text: -"Donald Trump cancels February visit to UK". BBC News. 12 January 2018. Retrieved 12 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 15 January  Carillion, the UK's second-largest construction company, goes into liquidation with debts of £1,500,000,000.

links.text: -"Carillion to go into liquidation". BBC News. 15 January 2018. Retrieved 15 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 16 January  Supermarket chain Iceland announces that it will end the use of plastic for its own-brand products by the end of 2023.

links.text: -"Iceland supermarket chain aims to be plastic free by 2023". BBC News. 16 January 2018. Retrieved 16 January 2018.-
-"ICELAND AIMS TO BE PLASTIC-FREE ACROSS OWN LABEL RANGE BY 2023" (PDF). Iceland. 16 January 2018. Retrieved 16 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: French President Emmanuel Macron agrees to loan the Bayeux Tapestry to the United Kingdom; the first time in 950 years it will have left France.

links.text: -"Bayeux Tapestry to be displayed in UK for the first time". BBC News. 17 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: By 317 to 299 votes, the Conservatives reject a Labour amendment to keep the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

links.text: -"Tory government votes not to retain European human rights charter in UK law after Brexit". The Independent. 17 January 2018. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 18 January 2018.-
-"Tory government votes not to retain European human rights charter in UK law after Brexit". The Independent. 17 January 2018. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 18 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 18 January  Scotland Yard says that American actor Kevin Spacey is being investigated over a third accusation of sexual assault, dating from 2005.

links.text: -"Kevin Spacey: Scotland Yard investigates third sexual assault claim against actor". The Guardian. 18 January 2018. Retrieved 18 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 21 January  The UK Independence Party's National Executive Committee (NEC) delivers a vote of no confidence in its leader, Henry Bolton, following a recent controversy involving his girlfriend.
23 January  Rupert Murdoch’s £11,700,000,000 bid to take full control of Sky is provisionally blocked by the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA).

links.text: -"Rupert Murdoch's Sky bid provisionally blocked by regulator". The Guardian. 23 January 2018. Retrieved 23 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 24 January  Sir Elton John announces that he is to retire from touring after nearly fifty years.

links.text: -Nevins, Jake (24 January 2018). "Elton John retires from touring … with 300-date world tour". The Guardian. Retrieved 11 January 2024.-

Data.event_text: Industry body Water UK announces that all shops, cafés, and businesses in England will provide free water refill points in every major city and town by 2021.

links.text: -"Plastic bottles: Free water refill points rolled out to cut waste". BBC News. 25 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: The number of rough sleepers in England reaches its highest level since records began  an estimated 4,751.

links.text: -"Rough sleeping in England rises for seventh year". BBC News. 25 January 2018. Retrieved 25 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 30 January  A leaked government paper shows that Brexit will damage the UK economy no matter what kind of deal is agreed, with up to 8% of GDP growth lost within fifteen years.

links.text: -"Any Brexit deal will hit UK economy – government paper". BBC News. 30 January 2018. Retrieved 30 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 2 February  Finsbury Park Mosque attacker Darren Osborne, who drove a van into a group of Muslims, is jailed for life, with a minimum term of 43 years.

links.text: -"Finsbury Park attacker Darren Osborne jailed for minimum of 43 years". BBC News. BBC. 2 February 2018. Retrieved 2 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: 3 February  British YouTuber KSI defeats fellow British YouTuber Joe Weller in 3 rounds in a YouTube boxing match at the Copper Box Arena. The event was viewed by up to 1.6 million people on live streams.

links.text: -Sharman, Jon (6 February 2018). "KSI vs Joe Weller: Millions watch YouTube stars' boxing match". The Independent.-

Data.event_text: The chief constable of Police Scotland, Phil Gormley, resigns amid a series of investigations into claims of gross misconduct.

links.text: -"Police Scotland chief constable quits". BBC News. BBC. 7 February 2018. Retrieved 7 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: Jon Venables, one of the killers of toddler James Bulger, is jailed for possessing child abuse images for a second time.

links.text: -"Bulger killer jailed for indecent images". BBC News. 7 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: 8 February  NHS hospitals in England record their worst ever A&E performance, with only 77.1% of patients treated within four hours in January, far short of the 95% target.

links.text: -"NHS hospitals in England record worst ever A&E performance". The Guardian. 8 February 2018. Retrieved 8 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: Trinity Mirror, publisher of the traditionally Labour-supporting Daily Mirror purchases Northern & Shell, chaired by Richard Desmond, publisher of the traditionally Conservative-supporting Daily Express, for £126,700,000, soon afterwards changing the group name to Reach.

links.text: -"Mirror buys Express titles from Richard Desmond". BBC News. 9 February 2018.-
-"Daily Mirror owner changes name to Reach". BBC News. 5 March 2018. Retrieved 6 September 2020.-

Data.event_text: An investigation by The Times newspaper finds that Oxfam covered up the use of prostitutes by senior aid workers overseas.

links.text: -"Minister orders Oxfam to hand over files on Haiti prostitute scandal". The Times. 9 February 2018. Retrieved 12 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: An earthquake of magnitude 4.4 and depth of 7.4 km hits South Wales, the biggest in the UK since the 2008 Lincolnshire earthquake. The effects are felt as far away as Liverpool, Birmingham and Cornwall.

links.text: -"UK hit by biggest earthquake for a decade". Sky News. 17 February 2018. Retrieved 17 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: UKIP members vote to dismiss party leader Henry Bolton after controversy over racist text messages sent by his partner.

links.text: -"UKIP members voted to sack embattled leader Henry Bolton". BBC News. 17 February 2018. Retrieved 17 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: 21 February  The National Farmers Union elects Minette Batters, the first female president in its 110-year history.

links.text: -"NFU elects first female president". BBC News. 21 February 2018. Retrieved 22 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: 22 February  The 2018 UK higher education strike begins with academic staff at sixty-four UK universities over proposed changes to the USS pension scheme.

links.text: -"UCU announces 14 strike dates at 61 universities in pensions row". www.ucu.org.uk. Retrieved 13 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: US cable TV giant Comcast makes a £22,100,000,000 bid for Sky, challenging an existing offer from 21st Century Fox.

links.text: -"Rupert Murdoch's Sky bid challenged by Comcast". BBC News. 27 February 2018. Retrieved 27 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: The Labour Party appoints transgender model Munroe Bergdorf as an LGBT adviser to Shadow Secretary of State for Women and Equalities Dawn Butler.

links.text: -"Munroe Bergdorf: Trans model becomes Labour's LGBT adviser". BBC News. BBC. 27 February 2018. Retrieved 27 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: Snow in a rural part of North Wales27 February  4 March  Heavy snow causes disruption across much of the UK. Over subsequent days the Met Office issues the first ever red snow warning for Scotland, South West England and South Wales, meaning the weather poses a potential risk to life. With ten severe weather warnings in place, the Army is called in to help rescue hundreds of stranded motorists. Several people are reported to have died in circumstances related to the freezing conditions. As temperatures later begin rising and ice thaws, the Environment Agency issues weather warnings due to flooding, mainly in the South-West and North-East England.

links.text: -"UK weather: Heavy snow causes UK-wide disruption". BBC News. 27 February 2018. Retrieved 27 February 2018.-
-"UK weather: Snow causing widespread travel disruption". BBC News. BBC. 28 February 2018. Retrieved 28 February 2018.-
-"Storm Emma: Red warning in Wales and south-west England". BBC News. 1 March 2018.-
-"Storm Emma: Army called in to rescue drivers stuck in snow". BBC News. 2 March 2018. Retrieved 2 March 2018.-
-"Extreme weather strands train passengers and hundreds of motorists overnight". ITV News. 2 March 2018. Retrieved 2 March 2018.-
-"UK weather: Warnings remain as temperatures set to rise". BBC News. 3 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: The UK's largest toy retailer, Toys "R" Us, goes into administration with a £15,000,000 VAT bill it is unable to pay.

links.text: -"Toys R Us UK goes into administration". BBC News. 28 February 2018. Retrieved 28 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: One of the UK's biggest electronics retailers, Maplin, goes into administration after talks with potential buyers fail to secure a sale.

links.text: -"Maplin collapses as rescue talks fail". BBC News. 28 February 2018. Retrieved 28 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: An earthquake of magnitude 3.2 and depth of 4 km hits Mosser, Cumbria. It is felt in Grasmere, Kendal, Cockermouth and Keswick and is the second earthquake to hit the United Kingdom within two weeks.

links.text: -"Cumbria earthquake: Houses shake as tremor of 3.2 magnitude hits county". Sky News. 28 February 2018.-

Data.event_text: Paper £10 notes featuring Charles Darwin cease to be legal tender in the UK.

links.text: -Treanor, Jill (14 November 2017). "Old £10 notes will expire on 1 March 2018, says Bank of England". The Guardian. Retrieved 25 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: Former Mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, is suspended from the Labour Party indefinitely, amid claims of anti-semitism.

links.text: -"Labour suspends Ken Livingstone indefinitely over anti-Semitism claims". BBC News. 1 March 2018. Retrieved 1 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Police forensics tent in the cordoned of area of Salisbury following the poisonings4 March  Former Russian double agent Sergei Skripal and daughter Yulia are poisoned with a publicly unidentified nerve agent in Salisbury. They are brought to hospital in critical condition, along with a police officer who was first on the scene. Counter-terrorism police investigate amid speculation the Kremlin was behind the incident.

links.text: -"Russian spy 'attacked with nerve agent'". BBC News. 7 March 2018. Retrieved 8 March 2018.-
-"Ex-Russian spy collapsed with daughter". BBC News. 6 March 2018. Retrieved 7 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: After the recent cold spell, homes across the UK have water supply problems and thousands of people in Wales and South-East England are urged to use as little as possible.

links.text: -"Big thaw leaves thousands without water in parts of UK". BBC News. 5 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: A Sinn Féin delegation meets the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels about the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland due to Brexit.

links.text: -"Sinn Féin set for Brexit talks with EU chief". BBC News. 5 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: The sale of energy drinks to under-sixteens is banned by most UK supermarkets due to high levels of sugar and caffeine.

links.text: -"Energy drinks: UK supermarkets ban sales to under-16s". BBC News. 5 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: 6 March  Ex-UKIP leader Henry Bolton announces he will create a new political party called "OneNation" that would "campaign unceasingly for our full independence from the EU", and "mirror some of the changes that I sought to bring to UKIP".

links.text: -"Ousted UKIP leader Henry Bolton 'to set up new party'". BBC News. 6 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Saudi Arabian Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman starts a three-day visit to the UK, amid protest concerns from Prime Minister Theresa May.

links.text: -"PM to raise Yemen concerns in Saudi crown prince visit". BBC News. 7 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Carbon emissions in the UK fall to the level last seen in 1890.

links.text: -"Cars buck falling CO2 emissions trend". BBC News. 7 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: The EU rejects Theresa May's proposal for "mutual recognition" of standards between the UK and EU as part of a post-Brexit trade relationship, while also ruling out British membership of EU regulators such as the European Medicines Agency after Brexit.

links.text: -"Brexit: EU rejects Theresa May's trade plan and warns the UK will suffer 'negative economic consequences'". The Independent. 7 March 2018. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022.-
-"Brexit: EU rejects Theresa May's trade plan and warns the UK will suffer 'negative economic consequences'". The Independent. 7 March 2018. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022.-

Data.event_text: 11 March  Following the events of 4 March, up to 500 pub-goers and diners in Salisbury are told to wash possessions after traces of a nerve agent are found.

links.text: -"Russian spy: Salisbury diners told to wash possessions". BBC News. 11 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: The government confirms that online porn age checks will be delayed and will no longer be introduced in April.

links.text: -"Online porn age checks delayed in UK". BBC News. 12 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Meghan Markle joins the Queen for her first official event at a service to mark Commonwealth Day.

links.text: -"Meghan Markle joins Queen for Commonwealth Day service". BBC News. 12 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: The government's next fiscal statement, which is now called the Spring Statement is published.

links.text: -"Spring Statement will be on 13 March 2018". BBC News. BBC. 6 December 2017.-
-"Spring Statement: Philip Hammond hails better debt and growth forecasts". BBC News. BBC. 13 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Russian exile Nikolai Glushkov is found dead at his London home. Police launch a murder investigation three days later.

links.text: -"Russian exile Nikolai Glushkov found dead at his London home". The Guardian. 13 March 2018.-
-"Murder inquiry over Russian's London death". BBC News. 16 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Stephen Hawking, world-renowned theoretical physicist, author, and cosmologist, dies at his home in Cambridge, aged 76.

links.text: -"Stephen Hawking: Tributes pour in for 'inspirational' physicist". BBC News. 14 March 2018. Retrieved 14 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: It is reported that all "Toys R Us" stores in the UK will close within six weeks following the chain's collapse into administration in February and its failure to find a buyer.

links.text: -"All Toys R Us stores to close their doors". BBC News. 14 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: The government calls for an urgent meeting of the UN Security Council to discuss the poisoning of Sergei Skripal and Yulia Skripal on 4 March. Theresa May announces that 23 Russian diplomats will be expelled from the UK after Russia fails to respond to claims of involvement.

links.text: -"Russian spy: UK to expel 23 Russian diplomats". BBC News. BBC. 14 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Following the events of 4 March, Theresa May visits Salisbury. In a joint statement, the leaders of the UK, US, France, and Germany say the ex-spy poisoning was the first offensive use of a nerve agent in Europe since the Second World War, and that Russian involvement is the "only plausible explanation".

links.text: -"Theresa May visits Salisbury after spy attack". BBC News. 15 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: The Space Industry Act 2018 becomes law, giving UK spaceports the legal framework to function.

links.text: -"The UK's spaceport ambitions inch closer to reality". engadget. 15 March 2018. Retrieved 18 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: 1719 March  Heavy snow affects much of the UK. It is dubbed the "mini beast from the east"; a sequel to the previous cold wave at the start of the month. On 17 March, amber weather warnings are issued for North-West England, Yorkshire, the Midlands, London and South-East England. On 18 March, they are issued for South-West England, South-East England, mid-Wales and the West Midlands. Dozens of vehicles were stuck overnight on the A30 in Devon whilst two weather warnings remained still in place for much of the UK after wintry showers disrupted many parts of the country.

links.text: -"'Mini Beast from the East' brings snow and ice to parts of UK". BBC News. 17 March 2018.-
-"Snow and ice bring the UK to travel disruption". BBC News. 18 March 2018.-
-"Drivers stranded on A30 in Devon amid heavy snow". BBC News. 19 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: 1819 March  Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson dismisses claims from Russian EU ambassador, Vladimir Chizhov, who said that Porton Down may have been the source of the nerve agent. It is reported that experts from the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons will arrive on 19 March to test samples of the substance.

links.text: -"Spy poisoning: Russia stockpiling nerve agent, says Johnson". BBC News. 18 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: The Gambling Commission recommends that fixed odds betting terminals should be cut to £30 or less from £100.

links.text: -"Betting machine wagers 'should be cut to £30 or less'". BBC News. 19 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: David Davis meets Michel Barnier in Brussels to finalise details of the Brexit transition period after .

links.text: -"Davis and Barnier hope to agree Brexit transition terms". BBC News. 19 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Channel 4 airs a documentary about Cambridge Analytica, the data analysis company that worked on the successful Leave.EU campaign advocating British withdrawal from the EU, and for Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign. Undercover reporters, talking to executives from the firm, discover the use of bribes, honey traps, fake news campaigns, and operations with ex-spies to swing election campaigns around the world. An emergency court order is requested to raid the Cambridge Analytica offices.

links.text: -"Revealed: Trump's election consultants filmed saying they use bribes and sex workers to entrap politicians". Channel 4 News. 19 March 2018. Retrieved 19 March 2018.-
-"Cambridge Analytica: Warrant sought to inspect company". BBC News. 19 March 2018. Retrieved 19 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg receives a formal request from the UK Government to answer questions regarding Cambridge Analytica and the "catastrophic failure of process" behind the data breach.

links.text: -"UK Parliament summons Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg to be questioned over Cambridge Analytica scandal". The Independent. 20 March 2018. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 20 March 2018.-

-"UK Parliament summons Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg to be questioned over Cambridge Analytica scandal". The Independent. 20 March 2018. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 20 March 2018.-
-"Cambridge Analytica: Mark Zuckerberg asked to appear before MPs". BBC News. 20 March 2018. Retrieved 20 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: The board of Cambridge Analytica suspends CEO Alexander Nix with immediate effect, pending a full and independent investigation.

links.text: -"Cambridge Analytica suspends CEO Alexander Nix". The Guardian. 20 March 2018. Retrieved 20 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: 21 March   Following eight years of the austerity programme, a pay rise is agreed for 1,300,000 NHS staff, with minimum increases of at least 6.5% over three years and some people getting as much as 29%.

links.text: -"NHS pay: Unions agree deal for 1.3 million staff". BBC News. 21 March 2018. Retrieved 21 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: 22 March  The Bank of England keeps UK interest rates at 0.5%, but hints that it will raise them to 0.75% in May.

links.text: -"Bank vote hints at interest rate rise in May". BBC News. 22 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Ahmed Hassan, perpetrator of the Parsons Green bombing, is sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 34 years.

links.text: -"Parsons Green Tube bomber Ahmed Hassan sentenced to life". Sky News. 23 March 2018. Retrieved 23 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn sacks Owen Smith from the Shadow Cabinet, for calling for a second EU referendum contrary to official Labour Party position. Smith is replaced by Tony Lloyd.

links.text: -"Jeremy Corbyn sacks Labour frontbencher over referendum call". BBC News. 23 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: 24 March  Plaid Cymru announces that if elected, they will hold an independence referendum for Wales by 2030.

links.text: -"Plaid Cymru 'would hold Wales independence referendum'". BBC News. 24 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: 25 March  The first scheduled direct flight from Australia to the UK—Qantas Flight QF9 from Perth—lands at London's Heathrow Airport after a seventeen-hour flight and 9,009 miles in the air.

links.text: -"First regular Australia-UK non-stop flight". BBC News.-

Data.event_text: The UK Government announces that consumers in England will soon pay a deposit when they buy drinks bottles and cans in a bid to boost recycling and cut waste, but consumers will get the money back if they return the container.

links.text: -"Drinks bottles and can deposit return scheme proposed". BBC News. 28 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: General Sir Nicholas Carter is named as the new Chief of the Defence Staff.

links.text: -Beale, Jonathan (28 March 2018). "General Sir Nicholas Carter named as Chief of Defence Staff". BBC News. BBC.-

Data.event_text: 31 March  The government receives a request from the Russian Embassy to visit Yulia Skripal in hospital after the poisoning on 4 March.

links.text: -"Russian spy: the UK considers a request to visit Yulia Skripal". BBC News. 31 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: All privately rented properties in England and Wales are required to have a minimum energy performance rating of "E".

The National Living Wage for people over 25 increases from £7.50 to £7.83 an hour. Workers between the ages of 2124 receive an hourly pay rise from £7.05 to £7.38, wages rise from £5.60 to £5.90 for 1820-year-olds, from £4.05 to £4.20 for 16–17-year-olds and £3.50 to £3.70 for apprentices aged under 19 or in the first year of their apprenticeship.
2 April  The Director of Public Prosecutions in England and Wales, Alison Saunders, announces that she will step down after her contract ends in October.

links.text: -"Director of public prosecutions Alison Saunders to stand down". BBC News. BBC. 2 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: Michael Gove announces that the sale of ivory of any age, with limited exceptions, will be the toughest ban in the world to reduce elephant poaching.

links.text: -"UK ivory ban among 'toughest' in the world, says Gove". BBC News. 3 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: London's murder rate surpasses that of New York City.

links.text: -"London murder rate surpasses New York – CNN Video". CNN. 3 April 2018. Retrieved 6 August 2018.-
-"London's murder rate surpasses New York's for 1st time ever". CBS News. 3 April 2018. Retrieved 6 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 5 April  All firms with at least 250 employees are required to publish data about their pay differences between men and women.
6 April  The sugary drinks tax comes into force throughout the UK.

links.text: -"Soft Drinks Industry Levy: 12 things you should know – GOV.UK". www.gov.uk. Retrieved 4 January 2018.-
-"Soft drink sugar tax starts, but will it work?". BBC News. 6 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: 11 April  A £70,000,000 plan to extend Birmingham's Alexander Stadium is announced for the 2022 Commonwealth Games and confirmed by Theresa May on a visit to the city.

links.text: -"Birmingham's Alexander Stadium in £70m revamp for 2022 Games". BBC News. 11 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: 13 April  The London Stock Exchange announces David Schwimmer as its new chief executive, to be appointed on 1 August to replace Xavier Rolet who quit the role the previous November.

links.text: -"London Stock Exchange names David Schwimmer as new boss". BBC News. 13 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: 14 April  The UK, France, and United States order the bombing of Syrian military bases, in response to a sarin chemical attack allegedly by the Bashar al-Assad regime on civilians in Ghouta.

links.text: -"As it happened: The strike and its aftermath". 14 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: 17 April  Theresa May apologises to Caribbean leaders at Downing Street over the Windrush generation controversy.

links.text: -"Windrush generation: Theresa May apologises to Caribbean leaders". BBC News. 17 April 2018. Retrieved 18 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: 18 April  Theresa May suffers two defeats in the House of Lords on her flagship Brexit legislation. In the first, the Lords vote by 348 to 225 to force negotiation of a Customs Union between the EU and the UK. In the second, the Lords vote by 314 to 217 on an amendment limiting the ability of ministers to use secondary legislation to water down existing EU rights when those rights get transferred to UK law.

links.text: -"Brexit: Ministers suffer first defeat on EU Withdrawal Bill". BBC News. 18 April 2018. Retrieved 18 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: Theresa May proposes a ban on plastic straws and cotton buds in England.

links.text: -"Plastic straw and cotton bud ban proposed". BBC News. 19 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: The UK experiences its hottest day in April since 1949, with temperatures of 28.5 °C (83.3 °F) recorded in Central London.

links.text: -"Hottest day in April since 1949 recorded". Sky News. 19 April 2018. Retrieved 19 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: 20 April  Commonwealth leaders announce that the Prince of Wales (now Charles III) would succeed Elizabeth II as Head of the Commonwealth.

links.text: -"Prince Charles to be next Commonwealth head". BBC News. BBC. 20 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: Mark Drakeford who will replace Carwyn Jones as first minister of Wales later in 201821 April  Carwyn Jones announces that he will stand down as First Minister of Wales in the Autumn, after nearly nine years in the role.

links.text: -"Carwyn Jones to quit as first minister after the 'darkest of times'". BBC News. BBC. 21 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: 22 April  The London Marathon takes place, amid the hottest temperatures ever seen at the event, reaching 24.1 °C (75.3 °F) in St James's Park.

links.text: -"London Marathon 2018 hottest on record". BBC News. BBC. 22 April 2018. Retrieved 22 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: Catherine Middleton (then Duchess of Cambridge) gives birth to a baby boy at St Mary's Hospital, London who becomes fifth-in-line to the throne and Elizabeth II's sixth great-grandchild. He is subsequently named Louis Arthur Charles.

links.text: -"Royal baby: Duchess gives birth to boy". BBC News. 23 April 2018.-
-Davies, Caroline (27 April 2018). "Duke and Duchess of Cambridge name baby son Louis Arthur Charles". The Guardian. Retrieved 2 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: Theresa May announces a national day of commemoration for a murdered teenager Stephen Lawrence, which will take place on 22 April every year. Eighteen-year-old Lawrence was stabbed to death on 22 , whilst waiting for a bus in Eltham.

links.text: -"Stephen Lawrence Day to be held annually". BBC News. 23 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: 24 April  The first statue of a woman in Parliament Square is unveiled, that of suffragette Millicent Fawcett.

links.text: -Hughes, Laura (24 April 2018). "Statue of suffragist Millicent Fawcett unveiled in London". Financial Times.-

Data.event_text: 26 April  Over forty companies including Coca-Cola and Asda pledge and sign up to the UK Plastics Pact to cut plastic pollution by 2025.

links.text: -"Companies sign up to pledge to cut plastic pollution". BBC News. 26 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: 29 April  Amber Rudd resigns as Home Secretary following the Windrush scandal. She is replaced the following day by Communities Secretary, Sajid Javid.

links.text: -"Amber Rudd resigns as home secretary". BBC News. 29 April 2018.-
-"Sajid Javid to be new home secretary". BBC News. 30 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: 2 May  Cambridge Analytica files for bankruptcy, following the data privacy scandal.

links.text: -"Cambridge Analytica: Closure "will not stop investigation"". BBC News. 3 May 2018. Retrieved 3 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: Elections for many local councils and mayoralties are held in England, including all 32 London boroughs. There are losses for the Conservatives (−33) and gains for Labour (+77), the Lib Dems (+75) and Green Party (+8). Meanwhile, UKIP is nearly wiped out, losing 123 councillors and retaining just three. Other parties see a net loss of four councillors.

links.text: -"England local elections 2018". BBC. 5 May 2018. Retrieved 5 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: A by-election is held at the West Tyrone constituency following the resignation of MP Barry McElduff in January.

links.text: -"Date is set for West Tyrone by-election". BBC News. 31 March 2018. Retrieved 6 April 2018.-

Data.event_text: 4 May  Órfhlaith Begley, a 26-year-old solicitor, retains West Tyrone for Sinn Féin in the previous day's by-election.

links.text: -"West Tyrone by-election: We've made history.. but lessons to be learned, says new MP Orfhlaith Begley". belfasttelegraph.co.uk. 4 August 2018. Retrieved 14 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: Matthew Hedges is arrested in the United Arab Emirates on suspicion of spying.
The UK experiences its hottest early May bank holiday (since its introduction in 1978) with a temperature of 28.7 °C (83.66 °F) recorded at RAF Northholt in West London.

links.text: -"Early May Bank Holiday weekend heat record broken". BBC News. 7 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: Mark Williams defeats John Higgins by 18 frames to 16 to win the 2018 World Snooker Championship.

links.text: -"World Championship: Mark Williams beats John Higgins to win third title". BBC Sport. 7 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: 8 May  Three votes take place in the House of Lords on the issue of Brexit. In the first, peers vote to remove the exit date of 29 March 2019 from the withdrawal bill, to give more time for negotiations. In the second, they vote to retain UK membership of EU agencies such as Euratom. In the third, they vote to give MPs a chance to vote on remaining in the European Economic Area, which would enable the UK to access the single market.

links.text: -"Theresa May forced to give MPs single market vote aftershock defeat". The Guardian. 9 May 2018. Retrieved 9 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: The Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson reaffirms the UK's commitment to the Iranian nuclear agreement after President Trump announces that the U.S. will pull out.

links.text: -"Iran nuclear deal: UK won't walk away, says Boris Johnson". BBC News. 9 May 2018. Retrieved 9 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: BMW announces the recall of 312,000 cars, after an investigation by the BBC's Watchdog finds a problem with vehicles stalling.

links.text: -"BMW recalls 300,000 cars that risk stalling completely". BBC News. 9 May 2018. Retrieved 9 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: The campaign group Leave.EU is fined £70,000 for breaching electoral law in the 2016 EU Referendum.

links.text: -"Brexit: Leave.EU fined £70,000 for breaking electoral law during referendum". BBC News. 11 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: Theresa May agrees to appoint a panel to help oversee the Grenfell fire inquiry, following pressure from campaigners.

links.text: -"Grenfell Tower inquiry panel broadened in apparent U-turn". BBC News. 11 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: First Minister Carwyn Jones confirms he will quit the Welsh Assembly at the 2021 general election.

links.text: -"Wales' First Minister Carwyn Jones to leave assembly in 2021". BBC News. 11 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: Stagecoach Group announces that rail services on the East Coast Main Line will be brought back under UK government control.

links.text: -"East Coast line to be put into public control". BBC News. 16 May 2018. Retrieved 16 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: Theresa May loses a 15th vote on the Brexit Bill, as the House of Lords votes, by 294 to 244, to create a watchdog for enforcing EU environmental standards.

links.text: -"May loses 15th Lords vote on Brexit bill as peers vote to keep EU environmental standards – Politics live". The Guardian. 16 May 2018. Retrieved 17 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: 17 May  The UK government announces that fixed odds betting terminals will be reduced to £2 under new rules, but bookmakers warns that the cut could lead to thousands of outlets closing.

links.text: -"Betting machine stakes cut to £2". BBC News. 17 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: The wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle is held at St George's Chapel, Windsor, with an estimated global audience of 1.9 billion.

links.text: -"Thousands Descend on Windsor for Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle". Variety. 19 May 2018. Retrieved 19 May 2018.-
-Davis, Caroline (15 December 2017). "Prince Harry and Meghan Markle to wed on 19 May". The Guardian. Retrieved 27 December 2017.-

Data.event_text: Chelsea F.C. win the FA Cup, beating Manchester United F.C. 10.

links.text: -Watson, Jack (19 May 2018). "FA Cup final, Chelsea vs Manchester United – as it happened: Eden Hazard penalty settles it for the Blues". The Independent. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022.-
-Watson, Jack (19 May 2018). "FA Cup final, Chelsea vs Manchester United – as it happened: Eden Hazard penalty settles it for the Blues". The Independent. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022.-

Data.event_text: 21 May  Former Mayor of London Ken Livingstone resigns from the Labour party, having been suspended since 2016 over allegations of anti-Semitism.

links.text: -"Ken Livingstone to quit Labour amid anti-Semitism row". BBC News. 21 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: A memorial service at Manchester Cathedral is held at 1430 BST, along with a national minute's silence, to mark the first anniversary of the Manchester Arena attack.

links.text: -"Manchester Arena attack: Anniversary to be marked in city". BBC News. 22 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: British retailer Marks & Spencer confirms the closure of 100 stores as part of their reorganisation of the company by 2022.

links.text: -"M&S to close 100 stores by 2022". BBC News. 22 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: 24 May  The chequered skipper butterfly, which became extinct in the wild in 1976 in England, is reintroduced within Rockingham Forest.

links.text: -"Extinct butterfly to be reintroduced in England". BBC News. 24 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) comes into force.

links.text: -"GDPR: US news sites blocked to EU users over data protection rules". BBC News. 25 May 2018. Retrieved 25 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport Vaughan Gething launches a consultation to ban smoking in outdoor grounds of hospitals, schools, and playgrounds within Wales from summer 2019.

links.text: -"Smoking ban plan for playgrounds and hospital grounds". BBC News. 25 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: Co-Leader of the Green Party, Caroline Lucas announces that she will step down from her position in September.

links.text: -"Caroline Lucas to step down as Green Party co-leader". BBC News. 30 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: Transport Secretary Chris Grayling says that the "rail industry has collectively failed" passengers after timetable changes caused chaos across the network.

links.text: -"Chris Grayling says GTR and Northern rail 'wholly unsatisfactory'". BBC News. 30 May 2018. Retrieved 30 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: The first 3D printed human corneas are created at Newcastle University.

links.text: -"3D printed human corneas created at Newcastle University". FT. 30 May 2018. Retrieved 31 May 2018.-

Data.event_text: 1 June  The Met Office confirms that May 2018 was the warmest since records began in 1910 and were also likely to be the sunniest since 1929.

links.text: -"May was sunniest and warmest ever recorded in the UK". ITV News. Retrieved 2 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: 5 June  The government approves a controversial plan for a third runway at Heathrow Airport.

links.text: -"Heathrow Airport: Cabinet approves new runway plan". BBC News. 5 June 2018. Retrieved 5 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: 7 June  Human rights campaigners lose a Supreme Court appeal over the legality of Northern Ireland's abortion law, but a majority of judges say the existing law was incompatible with human rights law in cases of fatal fetal abnormality and sexual crime.

links.text: -"Supreme Court rejects NI abortion law case". BBC News. 7 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: 8 June  Scottish drinks company Highland Spring announces that it will become the first UK water brand to introduce and trial a 100% recycled bottle in a bid to cut ocean pollution.

links.text: -"Highland Spring trials UK's first 100% recycled bottle". BBC News. 8 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: 12 June  A 15,000 person rally is held in support of Tommy Robinson, an English far-right activist.

links.text: -Gayle, Damien (11 June 2018). "Protesters charged after pro-Tommy Robinson rally in London". The Guardian.-

Data.event_text: 13 June  By 327 votes to 126, the House of Commons rejects a Lords amendment to the EU Withdrawal Bill, which had attempted to keep the UK in the European Economic Area after Brexit. Other changes made to the bill are also overturned, including a requirement to negotiate a customs union with the EU.

links.text: -"Brexit: MPs reject bid to stay in EEA amid Labour revolt". BBC News. 13 June 2018. Retrieved 13 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: 14 June  The Lewisham East by-election is held, with Labour winning the vote, but with a significantly reduced majority.
A bill that would make upskirting a criminal offence is blocked in the House of Commons by Tory MP Sir Christopher Chope. He faces criticism from those within his own party, including Theresa May.

links.text: -"Upskirting law to be passed soon, says Theresa May". BBC News. 16 June 2018. Retrieved 16 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: The Macintosh building at the Glasgow School of Art is gutted by another huge fire, four years after part of the same building was destroyed by fire. The fire spreads to close by buildings, including the Campus nightclub and O2 ABC music venue, which suffers "extensive damage". The Scottish Fire and Rescue Service reports no casualties.

links.text: -"Glasgow fire: Art school's Mackintosh building ravaged". BBC News. 15 June 2018. Retrieved 16 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: 17 June  The government announces an extra £20bn for the NHS by 2023, a budget increase of 3.4% a year. However, this is less than the average 3.7% the NHS had over the previous 70 years. The plan is also criticized by former Treasury officials, who cast doubt on the idea of a "Brexit dividend" and say the extra public spending will require higher taxes or public borrowing.

links.text: -"NHS gets £20bn 'birthday present'". BBC News. 17 June 2018. Retrieved 17 June 2018.-
-"Doubts cast on 'Brexit dividend' for National Health Service". FT. 15 June 2018. Retrieved 17 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: It becomes illegal in England and Scotland to sell rinse-off cosmetics and personal care products that contain microbeads.

links.text: -"World leading microbeads ban comes into force".-

Data.event_text: The government announces a review into the use of cannabis for medicinal purposes.

links.text: -"Medicinal cannabis use to be reviewed by government". BBC News. 19 June 2018. Retrieved 20 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: Theresa May condemns the forced separation of migrant children from their parents in the US, but dismisses calls to cancel President Donald Trump's visit to the UK.

links.text: -"US child detention pictures disturbing – Theresa May". BBC News. 20 June 2018. Retrieved 20 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: A rebellion by Conservative MPs is defeated, as the House of Commons votes by 319 to 303 against a "meaningful vote", which could have given MPs the power to stop the United Kingdom leaving the EU without a deal.

links.text: -"Brexit 'meaningful vote': May wins after rebels accept compromise". The Guardian. 20 June 2018. Retrieved 20 June 2018.-
-"Brexit: Theresa May wins 'meaningful vote' battle". BBC News. 20 June 2018. Retrieved 20 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: 23 June  Around 100,000 anti-Brexit campaigners march through central London demanding a final vote on any UK exit deal. The organizers, People's Vote, say that Brexit is "not a done deal" and people must "make their voices heard", whilst James McGrory from pressure group Open Britain says there should be "a choice between leaving with the deal that the government negotiates, or staying in the European Union".

links.text: -"Brexit: Marchers demand final Brexit deal vote". BBC News. 23 June 2018. Retrieved 23 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: A series of record-breaking wildfires begin burning across the United Kingdom.

links.text: -"Winter Hill: Crews battle 'aggressive' merged moorland fire". BBC News. 1 July 2018. Retrieved 1 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: The East Coast Main Line comes back under government control, following the failure of the franchise.

links.text: -"East Coast train line back under public control". BBC News. 24 June 2018. Retrieved 24 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: England record their biggest ever victory at a World Cup game, winning 61 against Panama, with captain Harry Kane scoring a hat-trick to take the team through to the final sixteen.

links.text: -"World Cup 2018: England put six past Panama to reach last 16 – BBC Sport". BBC News. 24 June 2018. Retrieved 24 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: The UK experiences the hottest weather of the year so far, with temperatures reaching up to 29.4 °C (84.9 °F) in London. The highest temperature is recorded in St James's Park. The same location had experienced the year's previous record temperature of 29.1 °C (84.3 °F) in April.

links.text: -"Temperatures reach 29.4C on the UK's hottest day of the year". BBC News. 25 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: The government throws out plans for the Tidal Lagoon Swansea Bay, claiming the £1.3 billion project is not good value for money.

links.text: -"£1.3bn Swansea Bay tidal lagoon project was thrown out". BBC News. 25 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: 26 June  The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) warns that there is "no Brexit dividend", urging the government to "as a minimum" remain in the customs union and forge a deal that delivers "single market benefits". In the same statement, the SMMT says that investment in new models, equipment, and facilities in the UK has halved compared to the previous year.

links.text: -"Brexit uncertainty putting thousands of jobs at risk, says car industry". The Guardian. 26 June 2018. Retrieved 26 June 2018.-
-"UK automotive industry urges rethink on Brexit red lines as uncertainty bites". Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders. 26 June 2018. Retrieved 26 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: 27 June  The British Medical Association (BMA) votes to oppose Brexit "as a whole" and calls for a public say on any final deal.

links.text: -"BMA votes to oppose Brexit "as a whole" and calls for public final say on deal". BMJ. 27 June 2018. Retrieved 28 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: 28 June  The Washington Post reports that former UKIP leader Nigel Farage is being investigated by U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s team for his ties to Donald Trump's associates and Russian colluders.

links.text: -"How the 'Bad Boys of Brexit' forged ties with Russia and the Trump campaign — and came under investigators' scrutiny". The Washington Post. 28 June 2018. Retrieved 2 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 29 June  Professor Philip Alston, a special rapporteur on human rights and extreme poverty, says the UN will investigate the impacts of Tory austerity in the UK, the organisation's first such probe into an advanced European country since 2011.

links.text: -"UN to investigate extreme poverty in the UK – after nearly a decade of austerity". The Independent. 29 June 2018. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 30 June 2018.-
-"UN to investigate extreme poverty in the UK – after nearly a decade of austerity". The Independent. 29 June 2018. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 30 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: Thousands of people march through London to mark the 70th anniversary of the NHS and to protest against government cuts to the health service.

links.text: -"Thousands protest in London over NHS funding cuts". The Guardian. 30 June 2018. Retrieved 30 June 2018.-

Data.event_text: It becomes illegal to manufacture, import, or sell rinse-off cosmetics and personal care products containing microbeads in Wales.

links.text: -"Wales to ban microbeads from June".-

Data.event_text: 3 July  England's World Cup penalty shootout win over Colombia is watched by 23.6 million viewers, the highest peak audience for live sport since England played Portugal in the 2004 European Championships.

links.text: -"World Cup 2018: England penalties win over Colombia seen by 24m". BBC News. 4 July 2018. Retrieved 4 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 4 July  Counter-terror police investigate after a man and woman are exposed to the Novichok nerve agent near Salisbury, four months after a similar incident in the area.

links.text: -"Amesbury: Two collapse near Russian spy poisoning site". BBC News. 4 July 2018. Retrieved 4 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 6 July  Theresa May secures approval from the cabinet to negotiate a soft Brexit. This includes proposals to create a new UK-EU free trade area, the ending of free movement but with a new "mobility framework" for UK and EU citizens, and the ending of the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice but with the UK paying regard to its decisions in areas where common rules are in force.

links.text: -"Brexit: Cabinet agrees 'collective' stance on future EU deal". BBC News. 6 July 2018. Retrieved 6 July 2018.-
-"Statement from HM Government" (PDF). gov.uk. 6 July 2018. Retrieved 20 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 7 July  In the World Cup quarter-finals, England win 20 against Sweden, taking them through to the Semi-finals on 11 July. It is the first time they have reached this stage since 1990. The match is live-streamed online by 3.8 million people, making it the BBC's highest online-viewed live programme ever.

links.text: -"World Cup Quarter-Final live: Sweden v England – Live – BBC Sport". BBC News. 7 July 2018. Retrieved 7 July 2018.-
-"World Cup 2018: England's victory over Sweden seen by 20m fans". BBC News. 8 July 2018. Retrieved 8 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: Police launch an international murder investigation after Dawn Sturgess dies in Salisbury Hospital after being exposed to a "high dose" of novichok nerve agent in Wiltshire on 30 June.

links.text: -"Novichok: Amesbury poisoning couple 'had high dose'". BBC News. BBC. 9 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: David Davis resigns as Brexit secretary. Following this, one more DExEU minister, Steve Baker also resigns.

links.text: -Rayner, Gordon (8 July 2018). "David Davis resigns as Brexit secretary". The Daily Telegraph. Retrieved 8 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: Dominic Raab is appointed as Brexit secretary after David Davis' resignation.

links.text: -"Dominic Raab replaces David Davis as Brexit secretary". BBC News. BBC. 9 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: Boris Johnson resigns as Foreign Secretary, saying that the "dream is dying, suffocated by needless self-doubt". He is replaced by Jeremy Hunt.

links.text: -"Johnson quits amid Brexit row". BBC News. BBC. 9 July 2018.-
-"Boris Johnson's resignation letter in full". BBC News. BBC. 9 July 2018. Retrieved 9 July 2018.-
-"Jeremy Hunt replaces Boris Johnson amid Brexit turmoil". BBC News. BBC. 9 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: The Royal Air Force (RAF) marks its 100th anniversary with a flyby of 100 aircraft over London and South East England. The Queen, accompanied by The Prince of Wales, also presents a new Queen's Colour to the Royal Air Force at a ceremony on the forecourt of Buckingham Palace.

links.text: -"10 July Centenary Celebrations". MOD. Retrieved 10 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: Two vice chairs of the Conservative Party, Maria Caulfield and Ben Bradley, resign in protest at Theresa May's Chequers Brexit compromise plan.

links.text: -"Tory vice chairs quit over Brexit". BBC News. BBC. 10 July 2018. Retrieved 10 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 11 July  England is defeated by Croatia in the World Cup Semi Final, losing 21.
The government publishes its White Paper, The future relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union.

links.text: -"Brexit white paper seeks free movement for skilled workers and students". The Guardian. 12 July 2018. Retrieved 12 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: US President Donald Trump arrives in the UK. The four-day visit includes talks with Theresa May, tea with the Queen and a trip to Scotland. There are mass protests in London, featuring a six-metre-tall (20 ft) 'Trump baby' blimp flown over Westminster.

links.text: -"Donald Trump arrives in UK for start of contentious visit". The Guardian. 12 July 2018. Retrieved 12 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: The Lightning Seeds' single "Three Lions" reaches number one in the UK singles chart for the fourth time following England's achievements in the 2018 FIFA World Cup, making it the only song to reach number one on four separate occasions with the same artist lineup. By the following week the single has plummeted to number 97, setting a record for the fastest ever fall from the top of the charts.

links.text: -"Three Lions breaks chart record". BBC News. BBC. 13 July 2018. Retrieved 13 July 2018.-
-"Three Lions plummets out of the charts". BBC News. BBC. 20 July 2018. Retrieved 20 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: Business minister Andrew Griffiths resigns over a sexting scandal, and two days before the publication of a Sunday Mirror story about the scandal.

links.text: -"Minister Andrew Griffiths resigns over texts to women". BBC News. BBC. 15 July 2018. Retrieved 15 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 14 July  The RRS Sir David Attenborough is launched into the River Mersey by its namesake, Sir David Attenborough.

links.text: -Amos, Jonathan (14 July 2018). "Sir David Attenborough launches 'Boaty' polar ship". BBC News. BBC.-

Data.event_text: England finishes fourth at the 2018 FIFA World Cup, losing the Third place play-off 20 to Belgium.

links.text: -"World Cup 2018 third place play off as it happened". The Guardian. 14 July 2018. Retrieved 30 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 15 July  The ongoing heatwave and dry conditions lead to a huge grass fire on Wanstead Flats, East London, which becomes the largest incident of its kind ever dealt with by the London Fire Brigade.

links.text: -"Wanstead Flats fire: Crews 'praying for rain' amid heatwave". BBC News. BBC. 16 July 2018. Retrieved 16 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: England footballer Harry Kane wins the Golden Boot at the 2018 World Cup after scoring 6 goals in the tournament. Kane is the first Englishman to win the Golden Boot since Gary Lineker at the 1986 World Cup.

16 July  The government confirms that it will accept all four demands by the European Research Group. Downing Street insists they are all consistent with its recent Brexit white paper, but critics say the Chequers agreement of 6 July is dead. MPs vote by 305 to 302 in favour of the amendment.

links.text: -"May's Brexit climbdown shows Rees-Mogg deciding government policy, says Labour – Politics live". The Guardian. 16 July 2018. Retrieved 16 July 2018.-
-"Brexit: Government scrapes through Customs Bill vote". BBC News. 16 July 2018. Retrieved 16 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: Brexit campaign group Vote Leave is fined and referred to police for breaking electoral law.

links.text: -"Brexit campaign group 'broke electoral law', says Electoral Commission". BBC News. 17 July 2018. Retrieved 17 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: In a vote of 307 to 301, MPs reject a proposal to form a customs union if the UK and EU do not agree on a trade deal. However, in a separate vote of 305 to 301, they back an amendment to keep the UK in the European medicines regulatory network.

links.text: -"Brexit vote: Government defeats EU customs union bid". BBC News. 17 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 18 July  Sir Cliff Richard wins a privacy case against the BBC over its coverage of a police raid on his home. High Court judge Mr Justice Mann awards him £210,000 in damages.

links.text: -"Sir Cliff Richard wins case against BBC". BBC News. 18 July 2018. Retrieved 18 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 19 July  Conservative MP Philip Davies submits a letter of no confidence in Theresa May to the chair of the backbench 1922 Committee, saying he has "lost trust" in her ability to deliver the EU referendum result.

links.text: -"Tory MP Philip Davies submits letter of no confidence in Theresa May". The Independent. 19 July 2018. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 19 July 2018.-
-"Tory MP Philip Davies submits letter of no confidence in Theresa May". The Independent. 19 July 2018. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 19 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 23 July  In response to the ongoing heatwave, the Met Office urges people to "stay out of the sun" and issues a level 3 amber alert for the east and south-east of England.

links.text: -"UK heatwave: Met Office says stay out of the sun". BBC News. 23 July 2018. Retrieved 23 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 24 July  Home Secretary Sajid Javid announces that the UK government will not object to the United States seeking the death penalty for two suspected British members of ISIL  waiving its long-standing objection to foreign executions.

links.text: -"Britain would not block death penalty for IS 'Beatle' suspects". ABC News. 23 July 2018. Retrieved 6 August 2018.-
-Riley-Smith, Ben (22 July 2018). "Sajid Javid tells US: We won't block death penalty for Isil 'Beatles'". The Telegraph. Retrieved 6 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: Michel Barnier, the EU's chief Brexit negotiator, rejects the UK's proposal to collect customs duties on its behalf.

links.text: -"Brexit: Barnier rules out key UK customs proposal". BBC News. 26 July 2018. Retrieved 26 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: The ongoing heatwave reaches its peak; temperatures at Faversham reach 35.3 °C (95.5 °F)—the hottest day of the year.

links.text: -"July 2018". Met Office. Retrieved 9 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 29 July  Ministers reveal plans to send in the Army to deliver food, medicine, and fuel supplies if the UK leaves the EU without a deal. It is also reported that supermarkets are beginning to stockpile supplies.

links.text: -"Army on standby for no-deal Brexit emergency". The Sunday Times. 29 July 2018. Retrieved 29 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 30 July  The Supreme Court rules that legal permission is no longer required to end care for patients in a permanent vegetative state.

links.text: -"Supreme Court backs agreed end-of-life decisions". BBC News. 30 July 2018. Retrieved 30 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 31 July  Xeneral Webster, 19, is jailed for 17 years for the manslaughter of Joanne Rand, who died in June 2017, eleven days after he splashed her with acid. The case is the first acid killing in the UK.

links.text: -"Joanne Rand acid death: Man jailed for 17 years". BBC News. BBC. 31 July 2018. Retrieved 31 July 2018.-

Data.event_text: 2 August  The Bank of England raises the baseline interest rate from 0.5 to 0.75%, its highest level since March 2009.

links.text: -"Bank of England raises UK interest rates". BBC News. BBC. 2 August 2018. Retrieved 2 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 6 August  Boris Johnson is criticised for a column that he had written in the Daily Telegraph. As part of an article discussing the introduction of a burka ban in Denmark, Johnson said that Muslim women who wore burkas "look like letter boxes" and compared them to "bank robbers".

links.text: -"Johnson burka 'letter box' jibe sparks anger". BBC News. 6 August 2018. Retrieved 7 August 2018.-
-"Johnson 'won't apologise' for burka comments". BBC News. 7 August 2018. Retrieved 7 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: Sports Direct tycoon Mike Ashley steps in to buy department store House of Fraser for £90m, after the chain calls in administrators.

links.text: -"House of Fraser bought by Sports Direct for £90m". BBC News. 10 August 2018. Retrieved 10 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: The government announces that it will lower the screening age for bowel cancer in England from 60 to 50, to bring it into line with Scotland.

links.text: -"Bowel cancer screening to start earlier at age 50 in England". BBC News. 10 August 2018. Retrieved 10 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 14 August  A man is arrested  on suspicion of terrorism offences after a car is driven into people and cyclists outside the Houses of Parliament, causing injuries to three of them, before crashing into security barriers.

links.text: -"Westminster car crash: Man arrested on suspicion of terror offences". BBC News. 14 August 2018. Retrieved 14 August 2018.-
-"Westminster crash: Salih Khater named as suspect". BBC News. 15 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 15 August  Iain Livingstone is confirmed as the new chief constable of Police Scotland, having been in interim charge of the national force since last autumn.

links.text: -"Scotland's new police chief announced". BBC News. 15 August 2018. Retrieved 15 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 18 August  45 years after forming in 1973, folk rock band Runrig performs their last-ever show against the backdrop of Stirling Castle.

links.text: -"The Last Dance: thousands say farewell to Runrig". Herald Scotland. 18 August 2018. Retrieved 19 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 20 August  The government announces its intention to take control of Birmingham Prison from the private security company G4S after the Chief Inspector of Prisons said it had fallen into a "state of crisis", and described it as the worst prison he had ever visited.

links.text: -Shaw, Danny (20 August 2018). "'Crisis' prison taken over by government". BBC News. Retrieved 20 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 23 August  The government publishes the first in a series of guidelines for businesses and the public on how to prepare in the event of a "no deal" Brexit scenario.

links.text: -"UK's 'no-deal' Brexit plans warn of credit card fees". BBC News. 23 August 2018. Retrieved 23 August 2018.-
-"How to prepare if the UK leaves the EU with no deal". Gov.uk. 23 August 2018. Retrieved 23 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 25 August  British YouTuber KSI gets a majority draw in his YouTube boxing match vs American YouTuber Logan Paul at the Manchester Arena. The fight went down as the biggest event in YouTube history.
29 August  Former SNP leader Alex Salmond resigns from the party to avoid internal division amid sexual misconduct claims, which he denies.

links.text: -"Ex-SNP leader Salmond resigns from party". BBC News. 29 August 2018. Retrieved 29 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 30 August  Labour MP Frank Field resigns the Labour whip over "excuses for the party’s toleration of antisemitism". He retains his party membership, describing himself as an "independent Labour MP".

links.text: -Stewart, Heather; Walker, Peter (30 August 2018). "Frank Field resigns Labour whip over antisemitism crisis". The Guardian. Retrieved 30 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 31 August  Transport officials announce that the opening of London's £15bn Crossrail line  Europe's largest infrastructure project – will be delayed by nine months "to ensure a safe and reliable railway".

links.text: -"Crossrail delay: New London line will open in autumn 2019". BBC News. 31 August 2018. Retrieved 31 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 1 September  As part of the phase-out of incandescent light bulbs, it becomes illegal to import non-directional halogen light bulbs into the United Kingdom.

links.text: -"The light bulb phase out schedule / Lighting Advice – Lyco Direct". www.lyco.co.uk. 17 April 2016. Retrieved 4 January 2018.-

Data.event_text: 2 September  A huge fire destroys part of the Littlewoods Pools building, one of the most famous landmarks in Liverpool.

links.text: -"Liverpool's Littlewoods Pools building engulfed by fire". BBC News. 3 September 2018. Retrieved 3 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: The Met Office confirms that 2018 was the joint hottest summer on record for the UK, alongside 2006, 2003 and 1976, and the joint hottest for England, alongside 2022.

links.text: -"2018 joint hottest summer for UK". BBC News. 3 September 2018. Retrieved 15 September 2018.-
-Rhoden-Paul, Andre (1 September 2022). "Heatwave: England has had joint hottest summer on record, Met Office says". BBC News. Retrieved 1 September 2022.-

Data.event_text: Latest available data shows that SNP membership has overtaken the Conservatives across the UK for the first time, pushing the party of government into third place.

links.text: -"SNP membership overtakes Conservatives across UK". BBC News. 3 September 2018. Retrieved 3 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: 5 September  Two Russian nationals are named as suspects of the poisoning of Sergei and Yulia Skripal.

links.text: -"Salisbury Novichok poisoning: Russian nationals named as suspects". BBC News. BBC. 5 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: 6 September  The 659-megawatt Walney Extension, the world's largest offshore wind farm, opens off the coast of Cumbria.

links.text: -"World's largest offshore windfarm opens off Cumbrian coast". The Guardian. 6 September 2018. Retrieved 6 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: 18 September  Storm Ali leaves homes and businesses without power and effects road, rail and air travel, killing one man in Northern Ireland.

links.text: -"Storm Ali: Man killed as winds batter NI". BBC News. 19 September 2018. Retrieved 24 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: 21 September  Theresa May demands new proposals from the EU to break the "impasse" after her Chequers plan was rejected by EU leaders. The pound falls by its highest amount of the year so far.

links.text: -"May: EU must respect UK in Brexit talks". BBC News. 21 September 2018. Retrieved 21 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: 22 September  US cable giant Comcast wins a rare blind auction process for broadcaster Sky, set by the UK's Takeover Panel.

links.text: -"Sky: Comcast outbids Fox with £30bn bid for broadcaster". BBC News. 22 September 2018. Retrieved 22 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: 24 September  An inquiry hears testimonies from patients affected by the Contaminated Blood Scandal of the 1970s and 1980s, the worst-ever NHS treatment disaster.

links.text: -"Contaminated blood scandal: Inquiry 'must uncover truth'". BBC News. 24 September 2018. Retrieved 24 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: The Office for National Statistics reports that life expectancy improvements in the UK have stalled for the first time since records began.

links.text: -"Life expectancy progress in UK 'stops for first time'". BBC News. 25 September 2018. Retrieved 25 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: Labour Party delegates approve a motion that could pave the way for a second EU referendum if MPs are unable to agree over a Brexit deal.

links.text: -"Labour votes to keep referendum option". BBC News. 25 September 2018. Retrieved 25 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: 21st Century Fox announces it will sell its 39% stake in Sky UK to Comcast, ending Rupert Murdoch's three decade association with the broadcaster.

links.text: -"Rupert Murdoch ends Sky association with Comcast stake sale". BBC News. BBC. 26 September 2018. Retrieved 26 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: It is reported that MP David Rutley was appointed as a Minister of Food (the first since 1958) to ensure the protection of food supplies through the Brexit process.

links.text: -"UK appoints food supplies minister amid fears of no-deal Brexit". The Guardian. 26 September 2018. Retrieved 26 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: Three men become the first people to receive jail sentences for an anti-fracking protest in the UK.

links.text: -"Blackpool activists jailed for anti-fracking protest". Guardian. 27 September 2018. Retrieved 27 September 2018.-

Data.event_text: Paul Dacre becomes chairman and Editor-in-Chief of Associated Newspapers and stands down as Editor of the Daily Mail in the following month.
The ban on microbeads in rinse-off cosmetics and cleaning products is extended to Northern Ireland.

links.text: -"Microbeads ban should be extended to NI in the Autumn". BBC News. 11 July 2018. Retrieved 20 August 2018.-

Data.event_text: 2 October  The government announces that heterosexual couples in England and Wales will be given the right to enter into civil partnerships rather than marriage.

links.text: -"Civil partnerships: Law to be changed for mixed-sex couples". BBC News. 2 October 2018. Retrieved 2 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 6 October  In the latest march organised by All Under One Banner, tens of thousands of people march through Edinburgh in support of Scottish independence.

links.text: -"Tens of thousands of people have marched through Edinburgh in support of Scottish independence". BBC News. 6 October 2018. Retrieved 6 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 12 October  The Wedding of Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank takes place at the St George's Chapel at Windsor Castle.

links.text: -"Royal wedding: Princess Eugenie marries Jack Brooksbank". BBC News. 12 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 13 October  Storm Callum Parts of Wales experience their worst flooding in 30 years.

links.text: -"Storm Callum: Parts of Wales see 'worst flooding in 30 years'". BBC News. 13 October 2018. Retrieved 13 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 16 October  Pepper becomes the first robot to appear at a UK parliamentary meeting, talking to MPs about the future of artificial intelligence in education.

links.text: -"Robot 'talks' to MPs about future of AI in the classroom". BBC News. BBC. 16 October 2018. Retrieved 16 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 18 October  A case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (so-called "mad cow disease") is confirmed on a farm in Aberdeenshire, the first of its kind in Scotland for 10 years.

links.text: -"'Mad cow disease' at Aberdeenshire farm after BSE confirmed". BBC News. 18 October 2018. Retrieved 18 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 20 October  A march through central London demanding a vote on the final Brexit deal attracts an estimated 700,000 people, according to its organisers. A later official estimate reported the number to be 250,000.

links.text: -"People's Vote march: 'Hundreds of thousands' attending London protest". BBC News. 20 October 2018.-
-Malnick, Edward (5 January 2019). "People's Vote march was attended by a third of number that organisers claimed, official estimate says". The Telegraph. ISSN 0307-1235. Retrieved 20 December 2020.-
-Malnick, Edward (5 January 2019). "People's Vote march was attended by a third of number that organisers claimed, official estimate says". The Telegraph. ISSN 0307-1235. Retrieved 20 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 21 October  The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) reports that 80% of UK firms in their survey have cancelled or delayed investments due to Brexit uncertainty. The figure a year earlier was 3640%.

links.text: -"UK firms 'near point of no return'". BBC News. 21 October 2018. Retrieved 22 October 2018.-
-"8 out of 10 businesses say Brexit hits investment as speed of talks outpaced by reality firms face on ground". CBI. 21 October 2018. Retrieved 22 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 24 October  Westminster Magistrates' Court imposes the first conviction for running an unregistered school in England, when two defendants are convicted of operating the Al-Istiqamah Learning Centre from an office block in west London.

links.text: -Coughlan, Sean (24 October 2018). "Two convicted of running illegal school". BBC News. Retrieved 24 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 25 October  Gavin Williamson announces that women who serve in the Army are now able to transfer into infantry roles, including the special forces, such as the SAS.

links.text: -"SAS: Women allowed to join for the first time". BBC News. 25 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 27 October  Leicester City's owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha is killed in a helicopter crash outside the King Power Stadium.

links.text: -"Leicester City owner 'on board crashed helicopter'". BBC News. 27 October 2018. Retrieved 28 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 29 October  Chancellor Philip Hammond says the era of austerity "is finally coming to an end" as he delivers his third budget.

links.text: -"Budget 2018". BBC News. 29 October 2018. Retrieved 29 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 1 November  Doctors are able to prescribe cannabis products to patients in England, Wales and Scotland.

links.text: -"UK to allow doctors to prescribe cannabis-based medicine". The Guardian. 11 October 2018. Retrieved 11 October 2018.-

Data.event_text: 4 November  Ross Edgley, 33, becomes the first person to swim around the entire coast of Great Britain. His journey of 1,780 miles had lasted for 157 days.

links.text: -"Ross Edgley sets record for round Great Britain swim". BBC News. 4 November 2018. Retrieved 4 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 6 November  Renewable energy capacity overtakes that of fossil fuels in the UK for the first time, at 41.9 gigawatts.

links.text: -"UK renewable energy capacity surpasses fossil fuels for first time". The Guardian. 6 November 2018. Retrieved 6 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 9 November  Transport minister Jo Johnson resigns from the Cabinet and calls for a fresh referendum on Brexit, including an option to remain in the EU.

links.text: -"Minister Jo Johnson quits over Brexit". BBC News. 9 November 2018. Retrieved 9 November 2018.-
-"Why I cannot support the Government's proposed Brexit deal". Medium. 9 November 2018. Retrieved 10 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: Remembrance ceremony at a cenotaph11 November  The United Kingdom marks the 100th anniversary of the end of the First World War, with a wreath-laying ceremony at the Cenotaph accompanied by the ringing of church bells throughout the country, followed by a march past the Cenotaph of 10,000 people. In the evening there is a ceremony at Westminster Abbey and 1,000 beacons are lit nationwide.

links.text: -"Remembrance Day: Service rounds off Armistice commemorations". BBC News. BBC. 11 November 2018. Retrieved 12 November 2018.-
-"Armistice Day: How the centenary of the end of World War I is being marked". Sky News. 11 November 2018. Retrieved 12 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 14 November  Theresa May secures Cabinet support for her Brexit Withdrawal Agreement after "a long, detailed and impassioned debate".

links.text: -"Brexit deal: May wins cabinet support but hints at ministers' reservations – Politics live". The Guardian. 14 November 2018. Retrieved 14 November 2018.-
-"Cabinet backs draft Brexit agreement". BBC News. 14 November 2018. Retrieved 14 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 15 November  Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab resigns, stating that he "cannot in good conscience support the terms proposed for our deal with the EU". Further resignations follow Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey, Junior Brexit minister Suella Braverman, Northern Ireland minister Shailesh Vara, and Parliamentary Private Secretary Anne-Marie Trevelyan. The pound falls sharply in response.

links.text: -"Brexit: Dominic Raab and Esther McVey among ministers to quit over EU agreement". BBC News. 15 November 2018.-
-"Pound dives after Brexit resignations". BBC News. 15 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 16 November  Steve Barclay is named as the new Brexit Secretary, while Amber Rudd returns to the Cabinet as Secretary of State for Work and Pensions.

links.text: -"Steve Barclay named new Brexit Secretary". BBC News. 16 November 2018. Retrieved 16 November 2018.-
-"Rudd back in cabinet at work and pensions". BBC News. 16 November 2018. Retrieved 16 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 17 November  Thousands of protesters block the five main bridges over the River Thames in central London as part of "Extinction Rebellion", a campaign to raise awareness of climate change and biodiversity loss.

links.text: -"Thousands gather to block London bridges in climate rebellion". The Guardian. 17 November 2018. Retrieved 17 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 25 November  After more than 18 months of negotiations, EU leaders endorse the Brexit withdrawal agreement.

links.text: -"EU leaders agree Brexit deal". BBC News. 25 November 2018. Retrieved 25 November 2018.-
-"EU leaders back Theresa May's Brexit deal in Brussels". The Guardian. 25 November 2018. Retrieved 25 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 26 November  British academic Matthew Hedges, jailed earlier in the month for spying in the UAE, is pardoned with immediate effect.

links.text: -"British academic pardoned by UAE". BBC News. 26 November 2018. Retrieved 26 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 28 November  The government announces plans for the UK's first carbon capture and storage project.

links.text: -"UK's first carbon capture and storage project 'operational by mid 2020s'". BBC News. 28 November 2018. Retrieved 28 November 2018.-
-"Plan to enable first UK carbon capture project from the mid 2020s announced at world-first summit". Gov.uk. 28 November 2018. Retrieved 28 November 2018.-

Data.event_text: 29 November  Labour MP Lloyd Russell-Moyle reveals that he is HIV positive, becoming the first politician to announce his HIV status in the House of Commons, and only the second to publicly disclose they are living with the condition.

links.text: -"Lloyd Russell-Moyle: MP announces in Commons he is HIV positive". BBC News. 29 November 2018. Retrieved 2 December 2018.-

Data.event_text: 30 November  Sam Gyimah resigns as Minister of State for Universities, Science, Research and Innovation, saying that he cannot vote for Theresa May's Brexit deal.

links.text: -"Brexit: Minister resigns over Theresa May's 'naive' deal". BBC News. 1 December 2018. Retrieved 1 December 2018.-

Data.event_text: 1 December  The government confirms that it will not use the EU Galileo satellite system for defence or critical national infrastructure after Brexit.

links.text: -"UK to tell EU it will no longer seek access to secure aspects of Galileo". Gov.uk. 1 December 2018. Retrieved 3 December 2018.-

Data.event_text: 4 December  In a vote of 311293, MPs find the Government in contempt of parliament for failing to publish its full legal advice on Theresa May's Brexit deal. They also back Dominic Grieve's amendment to hand back control of Brexit to Parliament if the deal is defeated.

links.text: -"Brexit: Full legal advice to be published after contempt vote". BBC News. 4 December 2018. Retrieved 4 December 2018.-

Data.event_text: The Attorney General's full legal advice on the Brexit deal is published.

links.text: -"Exiting the EU: Publication of Legal Advice". Gov.uk. 5 December 2018. Retrieved 5 December 2018.-

Data.event_text: The 100,000 Genomes Project is completed by scientists in Cambridge.

links.text: -Walsh, Fergus (5 December 2018). "Faster diagnosis from 'transformational' gene project". BBC News. Retrieved 5 December 2018.-

Data.event_text: 10 December  The government delays the parliamentary vote on approving the European Union Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration, postponing it from the following day to 21 . The pound falls to its lowest level in 18 months.

links.text: -"Theresa May postpones Brexit deal vote". The Guardian. 10 December 2018. Retrieved 11 December 2018.-

Data.event_text: 12 December  Theresa May wins a vote of no confidence on her leadership of the Conservative Party by 200117.

links.text: -"Theresa May survives confidence vote". BBC News. 12 December 2018.-

Data.event_text: 16 December  Tolls for crossing the Severn Estuary between England and Wales are scrapped, 800 years after they were first introduced.

links.text: -"Severn bridges: Final day of at least 800 years of tolls". BBC News. 16 December 2018. Retrieved 16 December 2018.-

Data.event_text: 18 December  Manchester United sack manager Jose Mourinho after two and a half years in charge.

links.text: -"Jose Mourinho: Manchester United sack manager". BBC News. 18 December 2018. Retrieved 18 December 2018.-

Data.event_text: 19 December  Tens of thousands of passengers at Gatwick Airport experience flight disruption due to reported drone sightings over the airfield. Police were still hunting for the drone operator the following day. Two days later, the runway reopens for passengers.

links.text: -"Gatwick Airport: Drone sightings cause delays". BBC News. 20 December 2018. Retrieved 20 December 2018.-
-"Gatwick runway reopens after drone chaos". BBC News. 21 December 2018. Retrieved 21 December 2018.-

Data.event_text: 28 December  HMV goes into administration for the second time (the first was in 2013).

links.text: -"HMV goes into administration for second time in six years". The Guardian. 28 December 2018. Retrieved 28 December 2018.-
